values:
I just found out my ex bf is getting married tomorrow.
Next moment it felt like I had a huge lump of ice in my stomach. 
It's been nearly 10 years since I saw him, since we lived together and had a relationship. I broke up with him and perhaps I shouldn't be broken up about it, but I still think I liked him more than he liked me.
The relationship, the living with him, the realising that he didn't know me at all and really wasn't interested in me, the breaking up and the aftermath - it all hurt me so much, it hurt my very core and soul, and I guess it still affects me.
This is surprising, I haven't thought about him for a long while... I didn't think I'd feel this way.

I'm bitter and jealous and I don't see why he should be happy and get love. I'm not happy for him at all.
I know I should be a good person and be happy for him, but I'm not.
OK, deep down I probably feel like it's good for him but...right now, it just hurts.

I don't really care about the ESC - Eurovision Song Contest - but this year was quite good, and especially Sweden's Loreen with Euphoria.
And WE WON you guys!!
WE WON! :D

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TxzWZ4Y-dN0

"alles hat ein ende nur die wurst hat zwei" Grimm FTW
(translates as "everything has an end, only the sausage has two."
It's funny, my dad's said that in Swedish all my life but I never knew it was a German saying. :)
And I never thought I'd hear it in an American TV-show. LOL

Sergeant Wu is always priceless: “The answer is obvious. These murders were obviously committed by a barefoot man carrying a wolf.”

Somehow my life feels a little better by gettin Tweets from Gary Clark (Scottish musician), Bitsie Tulloch (from Grimm) and Colin Ferguson (from Eureka). :D


I know, I have a very sad existence but one must make the most of it. :D

About Internet-dating... 

What questions do you think are good to ask a person about? When he says: ask me anything you like. What do I want to know, really? I mean, what questions actually means anything?

Also, when a guy says: Tell me something about yourself - what should I tell him, what things does a guy want to know about me?

Truthfully, I have no clue about these things.

PLEASE pretty please help me out, with any kind of advice really. :D
Has anybody seen a scifi movie called Extracted, starring Sasha Roiz? I'd like to know where I can find it and need help. Pretty please?

1. Why is Captain Renards hair grey in this episode but not later?
2. What is the creature that we see in the bushes in the end of the episode?
3. What exactly does Adalind DO with the guy, does she have claws or how does she kill him? Just curious really... ;)

A really interesting article, written by none other than Tom Hiddleston. 

http://www.guardian.co.uk/film/filmblog/2012/apr/19/avengers-assemble-tom-hiddleston-superhero?intcmp=ILCMUSTXT9385

I think what's important to remember is, any form of art, no matter what genre it is or whether it's for kids or adults, can be inspiring and give strength to people.

Being Human UK. What a fantastic series! Dark, angsty, bloody, sometimes really scary and sometimes really funny.
I guess some would say that the drama is over the top and exaggerated, but I really like this style. I like strong emotions, and especially when there is no hope in sight. ;)
Yes, I said angsty. ;)

I'm watching season 4 now and the thing that I'm most fascinated by right now is the fact that Andrew Gower (Cutler) sounds and talks just like David Thewlis sometimes. It's freaky! They have the same sort of lips, the same speech patterns, the same accent...but not all the time. Sometimes he sounds a little different, then all of a sudden he gets angry or frustrated and you could close your eyes and easily imagine it being Thewlis. :D

I wrote about Michael Socha before, didn't I? He and his sister, so alike! Especially the eyes and eyebrows. :D
And yes, of course, their accents aswell.

My God, I just realised that Tom, the werewolf is played by Lauren Socha's brother! 
I mean, I knew there was something familiar about him and now it just hit me! The face, the voice, the accent - they're really alike, when you think about it. :)

And yes, the accents. They have such funny accents. I'm quite good at hearing British accents but theirs really confuse me sometimes, it's like a different language. ;)

A really really interesting article. You might not agree with everything, but read it and think about it. It really got me thinking...

http://www.cracked.com/article_19785_5-ways-modern-men-are-trained-to-hate-women.html

Finally back home! I've been away for a while, hence the absence from the computer and the journals. ;)
But now, I'm home. I really need to clean this place but I always seem to get distracted by something more fun.

I've just fallen in love with Grimm, which seems like a fun show to watch. I hope we're gonna see some more complicated plots than so far, but the characters are fun - love them all. :)
I really hope for some twist involving Captain Renard (Sasha Roiz)!
And Silas Weir Mitchell really looks like a wolfman. Kinda scary and crazy! :D

I've also started to watch season 3 of Being Human UK. Awesome. So dark and angsty, and still funny in some scenes. Love the drama, I really do! :)

I'm thinking about watching The Vampire Diaries, because therru has such good taste and she recommended it. :)

I also want to see the ending of Battlestar Galactica, plus the rest of Caprica (esp for Sasha Roiz).

Vogon poetry of the day:

See, see the warm sky
Marvel at its big brown depths.
Tell me, friend do you
Wonder why the frog ignores you?
Why its foobly stare
makes you feel tired.
I can tell you, it is
Worried by your intipott facial growth
That looks like
An onion.
What's more, it knows
Your penis potting shed
Smells of pea.
Everything under the big warm sky
Asks why, why do you even bother?
You only charm garbage.

Swedish-Iranian singer Laleh has a new album out. I listened to it on Spotfy and fell in love with this song immideately. It's amazing, both the lyrics and the melodies. Just so beautiful and special. "In the comet we found, there was more than just simple combinations of ice, dust and gas There were parts from a circus and parts from party dresses. Now, the best explanation for this, is someone has a party on another planet, and we're not invited The host has probably read the memories of an endangered beautiful elephant." youtu.be/1NWxamv5a6Q

I'm lying sick at home and a friend got me season 1 of The Office UK - hilarious! Martin Freeman looks like a kid, but damn he's awesome. Well, they all are. Funny, I never watched the show earlier, not the whole one anyway - but I really like it now that I'm watching it. :D

This is just so funny! :D

youtu.be/Tr0vARFXzlg


EDIT: Correction, it wasn't ACTUALLY a BAFTA but still - TOWIE won over Downton Abbey and Sherlock. Martin's face says it all. ;)

Originally posted by at To UK Flisties

If you're from the UK and you believe in freedom of speech and an uncensored interenet, you really need to sign this petition. There are others floating about, but that particular one is the best way to ensure that your voice gets heard. It's hosted on the directgov website and addresses parliament directly. If it gets more than 100,000 signatures, it becomes eligible for discussion in the House of Commons.

Everyone's been getting so worked up over SOPA -- and rightly so -- that ACTA seems to have slipped under the radar. This is hugely problematic, because ACTA is a similar bill, but it has the potential to be far more damaging than SOPA ever could be.

Some people seem to have this misconception that ACTA is the 'European SOPA', but that simply isn't true. It's a global treaty, and it's already been signed by eight countries, including the US, Japan, New Zealand and Singapore. Europe votes on Thursday. If they vote 'no', the bill will have to be taken back to the drawing board and reformulated, which should buy us some time at the very least.

If you think this doesn't affect you, you're wrong. If ACTA passes, it could well signal the end of the internet as we know it, and that isn't an exaggeration. It's not just about watching movies and television online. If ACTA passes, sites like YouTube, Livejournal, Tumblr, Twitter, Facebook and even Google and Wikipedia could become impossible to maintain. ACTA would allow ISPs to monitor your net activity and cut off internet access for your entire household if one person is suspected of breaching copyright. Think Big Brother is Watching. I don't think I need to emphasise just how damaging it can be to be without internet access in this day and age, when we rely so heavily on technology.

It's not only bloggers and fandom that would be affected, either. Small businesses, independent film-makers and unsigned musicians who have previously found their niche online would also suffer hugely, and would be at risk of being bullied into submission by Hollywood and multinational corporations under accusations of copyright infringement. All those artists who found fame by uploading covers of songs to YouTube would never have had the opportunity to do so under ACTA, as those cover versions would be prohibited.

I know the internet has its problems, but to my mind it's the single greatest invention to come out of modern times, and it would be an absolute travesty if we were to lose that now. From a personal point of view, I can't even put into words how important this is to me. I've met some of my closest friends through the internet and online fandom, people whom I would likely never have met without it, and it's given me this amazing social support system. I don't want that to end here, and I want to preserve it for future generations so that they can have the same experience and opportunities I've been given through my online interactions.

I know that opinions on the seriousness of copyright infringement and online piracy vary wildly, but that isn't really the point. Internet giants such as Google are opposed to this bill, and it's pretty safe to say that they're not in favour of copyright infringment, as anyone who's ever had a fanvid taken down from YouTube will be painfully aware. Whatever your stance on copyright, this isn't the way to go about dealing with it. This is dangerous legislation that impeaches on some of our most basic human rights, such as the right to privacy and freedom of speech.

So if you're from the UK, please, please sign the petition. If you hail from elsewhere in the world, there may well be similar movements in your own country, but I think the most effective thing anybody can do right now is to keep talking about this. Talk about it on Livejournal, on Twitter, on Tumblr, on Facebook, and anywhere else you can think of. Make sure this issue is never far from people's minds. The internet is an amazingly powerful tool: let's utilise it while we still have the chance.

Please repost and spread the word :)

SAY NO TO ACTA!

Please consider reposting this, especially if you have a large proportion of UK flisties. And please consider spreading the word via other platforms: Twitter, Tumblr, Facebook, your own personal network.

Requiescat in pace, Julie Noemi Peignen. I only met you once but you were a lovely wonderful woman who showed incredible generosity to my family. You let me and my sister borrow your flat in Paris during Christmas when we came to visit our family. 
From the moment I met you, I knew I would like you and perhaps I saw something of myself in you - like we often do. Now I know what it might have been... Were you sad or troubled? Did you feel lonely? Was the pain of life too much for you to bear? I will never know why you killed yourself but I know what it feels like in those moments when you feel despair and when you feel like there is no hope left.

You didn't show it when we met. You seemed incredibly happy and liked you enjoyed your life! Did something happen after that, that made you change? Or did you just hide it well?

I hope I can keep in my memory the few moments we shared together, and I am so sad that I will never get to know you better. I hope that if you feel anything where you are now, you will feel peaceful and loved.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:SOPA_initiative/Action


Wikipedia is an online encyclopedia that has been developed by tens of thousands of volunteers from all over the world over the last 11 years. Together, we have created millions of articles containing billions of facts, referenced to hundreds of thousands of sources from around the world. We have grown to be one of the most frequently accessed websites in the world. Wikipedians are fiercely proud and protective of our ability to freely share knowledge with the rest of the world, as the first of 846 related projects in 280 languages working under the umbrella of the Wikimedia Foundation.

In late 2011, the United States Congress proposed two legislative bills, the Stop Online Piracy Act (SOPA) and the PROTECT IP Act (PIPA), which legal scholars and others have advised have the potential to significantly change the way that information can be shared through the Internet. It is the opinion of the English Wikipedia community that both of these bills, if passed, would be devastating to the free and open web.

Over the course of the past 72 hours, over 1800 Wikipedians have joined together to discuss proposed actions that the community might wish to take against SOPA and PIPA. This is by far the largest level of participation in a community discussion ever seen on Wikipedia, which illustrates the level of concern that Wikipedians feel about this proposed legislation. The overwhelming majority of participants support community action to encourage greater public action in response to these two bills. Of the proposals considered by Wikipedians, those that would result in a "blackout" of the English Wikipedia, in concert with similar blackouts on other websites opposed to SOPA and PIPA, received the strongest support.

On careful review of this discussion, the closing administrators note the broad-based support for action from Wikipedians around the world, not just from within the United States. The primary objection to a global blackout came from those who preferred that the blackout be limited to readers from the United States, with the rest of the world seeing a simple banner notice instead. We also noted that roughly 55% of those supporting a blackout preferred that it be a global one, with many pointing to concerns about similar legislation in other nations. For example, one British editor stated "American law is America's business, but law that affects Wikipedia worldwide is an issue of worldwide interest", a principle we felt had considerable support.

Therefore, on behalf of the English Wikipedia community, the Wikimedia Foundation is asked to allocate resources and assist the community in blacking out the project globally for 24 hours starting at 05:00 UTC on January 18, 2012, or at another time as determined by the Wikimedia Foundation. This should be carried out while respecting technical limitations of the underlying software, and should specifically prevent editing wherever possible. Provisions for emergency access to the site should be included in the blackout software. In order to assist our readers and the community at large to educate themselves about SOPA and PIPA, these articles and those closely related to them will remain accessible for reading purposes if possible. Wikipedians are urged to work with WMF staff to develop effective messaging for the "blackout screens" that directs readers to suitable online resources. Sister projects, such as the German and Italian Wikipedias and Wikimedia Commons, have indicated an intention to support the same principles with banners on those sites, and the support of other projects is welcome and appreciated.

Internal Wikipedia processes that are dependent upon time-specific discussions, such as Wikipedia:Requests for adminship and Wikipedia:Articles for deletion discussion should be considered suspended during the course of the blackout, and their scheduled duration extended 24 hours.

Signed,

NW (Talk) 23:46, 16 January 2012 (UTC)
Risker (talk) 23:48, 16 January 2012 (UTC)
— billinghurst sDrewth 23:49, 16 January 2012 (UTC)

On behalf of the Wikimedia Foundation, I thank all editors who participated in the conversations, and we accept the recommendations, and will work hard to follow the recommendations to the best of our ability. Particular thanks to the closing administrators for their hard (and very fast!) work. Philippe Beaudette, Wikimedia Foundation (talk) 23:52, 16 January 2012 (UTC)

Damn you Martin Freeman for making me cry! Benedict Cumberbatch is a great actor but Martin Freeman is better, IMHO. He's just...great. I think he might be my new number one favourite actor. :)
I've seen him so many times, in small roles. I remember liking him even the first time I saw him, which was in the Office, and then his small role in Love Actually.
Of course, how could I not love him when he plays some of my favourite characters: Arthur Dent, Dr Watson and now Bilbo. :D

So, no spoilers for the Reichenbach Falls but like all the other episodes - marvellous. I love this show, love the actors.
Except for the guy playing Moriarty and his lines. Don't like them.
I keep thinking Mark Gatiss (playing Mycroft Holmes) would've been a much better Moriarty... And I don't know why they've written his lines the way they have, it was like whenever he said something it felt wrong and pathetic. Just off, somehow.

oh well, anyway, awesome series all and all. :D

Things I feel "fangirling" about at the moment:

  • The Avengers and the movies leading up to it. RDJ, Chris Evans, the whole gang. Joss Whedon, you'd better do a good job or I'll never forgive you. But you've always been a good director, IMO. A better director than a writer even, perhaps.
  • RDJ was born to play Tony Stark. He IS Tony Stark. Which might not be a good for him, though, but kinda hilarious anywyay.
  • Captain America, the movie, was actually good. I liked it. Had really low expectations but had to see it anyway, because I love superheroes. Chris Evans was surprisingly good, Hugo Weaving awesome - but that scene with "Heil Hydra" made me LOL derisively. So ridiculous. Still, I liked the movie and it had good music in it and a good sense of humour. Also I SQUEED when I saw Nick Fury. :D
  • Doctor Who, Matt Smith - so adorable. How could I not fangirl him? I love this last season, it's even made me love River Song - whom I hated before.
  • The Big Bang Theory - love it. Love all the characters and the show's just been better now that they have the girlfriends in it, I love Penny and Amy - they're hilarious! :D
  • Lord Of the Rings and all the actors surrounding it. I think it was the 10 yr anniversary and the making of the Hobbit that set this off again. :)
  • David Thewlis, still. :) Although I'm starting to suspect that he might be an ass in real life...but am trying to deny it. Also Gary Oldman. Also starting to suspect that I wouldn't like him in real life but am trying to ignore that also. I might just have to admit that they're grumpy old men who can still be good actors. ;)
I still haven't seen Thor, but it's on my list. Guess I have to see The Hulk too, since it kinda goes with The Avengers...
Also on my list of things I want to see: Tinker-Tailor-Soldier-Spy, The Hobbit, Sherlock Holmes 2, Anonymous, The Lady, Revolution of The Apes - or what is it called? And I want to see the rest of Game of Thrones, which I havent yet seen.

I'm kinda freaked out that 15 counts as a child in some countries and I keep forgetting about it until I read things like this:

http://www.tmz.com/2011/01/20/parents-television-council-skins-mtv-federal-investigation-underage-sex-child-pornography/

I guess you can't watch some Swedish movies then because they're 15 and have sex with each other? Even though that's not really graphic, sometimes they're nude...

OK, now I'm ranting, angry and bitter, again.

Seriously? I'd switch any day to have good looks, money, a good fucking job etc. if it meant being heckled one night by Ricky Gervais.

I should know better and I should be a better person...but I can't help but loathe Britney Spears and some other so-called artists, who spend more time looking like hookers than actually doing something really unique and creative with music.
Something that has a little more depth and meaning to it...

I know I have people on my F-list from Australia and I know some other people who live there too.

I just want you to know that you're in my thoughts and I hope that you'll be OK during this difficult time.

*big hugs*

Things are a little strange right now in Sweden but today is still the 13th of december, a day that's associated with music and singing.
An old tradition, we celebrate Santa Lucia. Sweden isn't really a religious country but we still celebrate many christian traditions, even those of us who are pagan or atheist do. ;)

Here are two clips with some lovely traditional Swedish Lucia-music.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7u4YPvw1ZUo


The second one is an hour long, with some Swedish talking that you can skip, but the singing is flawless.

http://svtplay.se/v/2265228/luciafirande_i_svt/lucia

I don't know if you'rew heard about it, but it seems like Sweden has had its first suicide bomber. :(

Yesterday, in Stockholm, a man blew himself up and a car exploded. Soon before this, an email was sent to the news, talking about an attack.

http://www.swedishwire.com/component/content/article/2:politics/7620:suicide-bomber-kills-one-in-stockholm

http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/12/11/sweden.explosion/index.html


Now, I know this might seem like nothing big to you living in big cities or countries, but for a small country like Sweden - nothing like this has ever happened before. :(

Fortunately, it seems like he only killed himself and that only two other people were hurt and not severely...but this means that it CAN happen, and it could have been so much worse if he'd been good at "blowing things up". :(

So yeah, it is kinda scary...

"On Thursday, Jimmy Jean-Louis finally received the phone call he had longed for: He spoke with his mother in Haiti.

"I got a phone call from my sister who said she was able to reach home," the Haitian native and "Heroes" cast member said. " So I picked up the phone and my mom answered. The first reaction from both of us was simply to cry." "

http://edition.cnn.com/2010/SHOWBIZ/TV/01/14/jimmy.louis.haiti/

It's so awful, one can't truly realise what it must be like. :(

One of my fave actors on Heroes, Jimmy Jean-Louis, is from Haiti: 


"I have not slept yet. The second house that I grew up in was down, and some relatives have died, from what I have been told," Jean-Louis said Wednesday. "I haven't been able to reach my parents. I have heard that they are OK, but I do not know what is going on around them."

http://community.livejournal.com/ohnotheydidnt/42945881.html

Post also contains link on how to donate money. My heart goes out to those who suffer. :(

Great movie, especially if you're a geek who's seen Star Wars a couple of times. Even funnier if you've seen Star Trek a couple of times too. ;)

So, naturally, I loved it. :D

It's got William Shatner, Billy Dee Williams, Carrie Fisher, Ray Parks (cool as always), Kevin Smith, Jason Mewes... If you're a geek, you know why they're in the movie. ;)

And Kristen Bell, who is brilliant as always. I totally loved her character and extra bonus points for getting the cutest geek, played by Jay Baruchel (who totally looks like a young Paul Dinello).

Minus points for being mean to Trekkies, but...you're forgiven.

Khaaaaaaaan! :D 

PS. where can I find my geeky guy? DS.
